text: We hear a lot about having the skills to thrive in ambiguity in order to be a successful product manager, but to be a successful product manager in news you have to be able to thrive in chaos. And equanimity is the most important skill I've developed I think across my entire life, and it's due to all of those years of practicing mindfulness and meditation. And equanimity is one of my favorite words, it means mental calmness, composure, evenness of temper, especially in crazy, stressful situations.
speaker: Upasna Gautam
context: Lenny asks Upasna about how her meditation and mindfulness practice helps her work at CNN, which he imagines is quite hectic with breaking news. Upasna explains that working in product at a news organization requires thriving in chaos rather than just ambiguity. She introduces the concept of equanimity - mental calmness and composure in stressful situations - as the most valuable skill she's developed through years of meditation practice.
text_ko: 성공적인 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)가 되려면 불확실성 속에서 잘 버티는 능력이 필요하다고들 많이 얘기해요. 그런데 뉴스업계에서는 그 정도가 아니라 혼돈 속에서도 잘 버텨내야 해요. 제 인생 전체를 통틀어 제가 길러온 가장 중요한 능력은 평정심(equanimity)이라고 생각해요. 그건 오랜 시간 마인드풀니스(mindfulness)와 명상(meditation)을 꾸준히 해온 덕분이에요. 평정심(equanimity)은 제가 특히 좋아하는 단어 중 하나예요. 뜻은 정신적 차분함, 침착함, 감정의 평정 같은 건데, 특히 정신없고 스트레스가 많은 상황에서 그런 상태를 말해요.
text_zh: 我们经常听说要想成为成功的产品经理，得有在模糊环境中游刃有余的能力，但如果你要在新闻行业做产品经理，那你必须能在一片混乱中还能干得风生水起。我觉得平常心是我这辈子培养出来最重要的能力，这都得益于我这么多年练习正念和冥想。平常心(equanimity)是我最喜欢的词之一，它指的是内心的平静、沉着，脾气稳定，特别是在那些疯狂的、压力山大的情况下。
text_es: Se habla mucho de tener las habilidades para desenvolverse bien en la ambigüedad para ser un product manager exitoso, pero para ser un product manager exitoso en medios de comunicación tienes que ser capaz de prosperar en el caos total. Y la ecuanimidad es la habilidad más importante que he desarrollado en toda mi vida, y se debe a todos esos años practicando mindfulness y meditación. La ecuanimidad es una de mis palabras favoritas, significa tranquilidad mental, compostura, mantener la calma, especialmente en situaciones locas y estresantes.

text: It's the ability to remain un-rattled in like the highest of highs and the lowest of lows. And if you think about it in the dynamic of a workplace or human interaction, it's really the ability to pause before reacting. And reactivity is the root cause of so many of our workplace woes and product management frustrations, and when you're able to pause before reacting you can start to undo and break a lot of those negative patterns in your brain.
speaker: Upasna Gautam
context: Upasna continues explaining equanimity and its practical application in product management. She describes how equanimity helps her remain calm during extreme situations and emphasizes that the core skill is pausing before reacting. She argues that reactivity causes many workplace problems and product management frustrations, and that learning to pause can help break negative behavioral patterns.
vocabulary_highlights: highest of highs and the lowest of lows
text_ko: 가장 기쁠 때나 가장 힘들 때에도 동요하지 않는 능력이에요. 직장 내 역학이나 사람들 사이의 상호작용을 생각해 보면, 반응하기 전에 잠깐 멈출 수 있는 능력이라고 할 수 있어요. 반응성(reactivity)은 많은 직장 내 문제들과 제품 관리(product management)에서의 불만과 답답함의 근본 원인이고, 반응하기 전에 멈출 수 있으면 마음속에 쌓인 그런 부정적인 패턴들을 풀어내고 끊어낼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 就是在最高峰和最低谷的时候都能保持淡定，不被情绪左右。你想想在职场上或者跟人打交道的时候，其实就是遇事先缓一缓，别急着反应。很多职场上的烦心事和产品管理(product management)上的糟心事，根子上都是因为反应太激烈了。如果你能做到先停一停再回应，就能慢慢打破大脑里那些负面的思维模式。
text_es: Es la capacidad de mantener la calma tanto en los momentos más altos como en los más bajos. Y si lo piensas en el contexto laboral o en las relaciones humanas, realmente es la habilidad de hacer una pausa antes de reaccionar. Y esa reactividad es la raíz de muchos de nuestros problemas en el trabajo y las frustraciones en la gestión de productos, y cuando logras pausar antes de reaccionar puedes empezar a deshacer y romper muchos de esos patrones negativos en tu mente.

text: I mean, you have to be ready to pivot at the drop of a hat. I had a big working session planned with my users to do research with them, or do user testing, and breaking news breaks, and it takes so much time and effort to gather a team of editors across the globe to do a user testing session. And when breaking news happens, they have to prioritize that over everything. So what do you do in that situation? You can be frustrated, absolutely it's frustrating. But we always have to have the ability to A, pivot of course, but also have backup and buffers in those types of scenarios.
speaker: Upasna Gautam
context: Lenny asks for a specific example of how Upasna uses her equanimity skills during chaotic moments at CNN. Upasna describes a common scenario where she has carefully planned user testing sessions with editors from around the world, but breaking news forces the journalists to abandon the session to cover the story. She explains how they build in backup plans and buffers to handle these frequent disruptions.
vocabulary_highlights: pivot at the drop of a hat
text_ko: 그러니까, 언제든지 바로 피벗(pivot)할 준비가 돼 있어야 해요. 사용자들과 큰 워킹 세션을 열어 사용자 리서치(user research)나 사용자 테스트(user testing)를 하려고 계획했는데, 갑자기 속보(breaking news)가 터지는 경우가 있어요. 전 세계 편집자들을 모아 사용자 테스트를 하려면 시간과 노력이 엄청나게 드는데, 속보가 나면 그걸 가장 우선순위로 처리해야 하거든요. 그런 상황에서 어떻게 하겠어요? 당연히 짜증나고 답답할 수 있어요. 하지만 우리는 항상 피벗(pivot)할 수 있어야 하고, 그런 상황을 대비한 백업(backup)과 버퍼(buffers)를 갖춰놔야 해요.
text_zh: 我的意思是，你得随时准备调整方向，说变就变。我本来安排了一个大型的用户工作会议，要做用户调研和用户测试，结果突发新闻一出来，你知道要召集全球各地的编辑团队来做用户测试有多不容易吧。可一有突发新闻，他们就得把这个放在第一位，别的都得往后排。遇到这种情况你能怎么办？沮丧肯定是会沮丧的，这确实很让人头疼。但我们必须具备这种能力，第一当然是要能够快速调整方向(pivot)，第二是在这种情况下一定要有备选方案和缓冲空间。
text_es: O sea, tienes que estar listo para cambiar de estrategia en un segundo. Tenía planeada una sesión grande de trabajo con mis usuarios para hacer investigación con ellos, o hacer pruebas de usuario, y de repente salen noticias de última hora, y cuesta muchísimo tiempo y esfuerzo juntar a un equipo de editores de todo el mundo para hacer una sesión de testing de usuarios. Y cuando pasan noticias urgentes, tienen que darle prioridad a eso por encima de todo. Entonces, ¿qué haces en esa situación? Te puedes frustrar, por supuesto que es frustrante. Pero siempre tenemos que tener la capacidad de A, hacer pivot obviamente, pero también tener plan B y colchones en ese tipo de escenarios.

text: When our engineers are able to understand our journalists' needs at the same level as we are, they're able to define the how to do it with so much greater clarity and precision. And so my tech lead is embedded also in our product discovery process, he joins our user testing sessions, and our design jams, and our editorial conversation planning sessions. And he's done an amazing job of also passing that knowledge down to the rest of our engineers on our team, so it's really like this mentality of getting that important feedback from our journalists, understanding their pain points and then sharing and teaching it across the team.
speaker: Upasna Gautam
context: Lenny asks about product review meetings and decision-making processes at CNN. Upasna explains how she evolved their approach by embedding engineers directly into the product discovery process rather than keeping them separate from user research. She describes how her tech lead now participates in user testing sessions and design activities, which helps engineers better understand journalist needs and determine technical feasibility with greater precision.
text_ko: 우리 엔지니어들이 기자들의 요구를 우리만큼 잘 이해하게 되면, 어떻게 할지(how to do it)를 훨씬 더 명확하고 정확하게 정할 수 있어요. 그래서 우리 테크 리드(tech lead)는 프로덕트 디스커버리(product discovery) 과정에도 함께 들어오고, 사용자 테스트(user testing) 세션이나 디자인 잼(design jams), 편집 기획 회의(editorial planning sessions)에도 참여해요. 그리고 그는 그 지식을 팀의 다른 엔지니어들에게도 정말 잘 전수해 줬어요. 결국 기자들로부터 중요한 피드백을 받고 그들의 페인 포인트(pain points)를 이해한 뒤 팀 전체에 공유하고 가르치는 그런 마인드가 자리 잡았어요.
text_zh: 当我们的工程师能够像我们一样深入理解记者的需求时，他们就能更清晰、更精准地找到解决方案。所以我让技术负责人也参与到我们的产品发现(product discovery)流程中，他会参加用户测试，参加设计头脑风暴(design jams)，还有编辑内容规划会议。他在把这些知识传递给团队其他工程师方面做得特别好，所以现在整个团队都有这种意识——收集记者的重要反馈，了解他们的痛点，然后在团队内部分享和传授这些经验。
text_es: Cuando nuestros ingenieros logran entender las necesidades de nuestros periodistas al mismo nivel que nosotros, pueden definir el cómo hacerlo con muchísima más claridad y precisión. Entonces mi líder técnico también está metido en todo nuestro proceso de descubrimiento de producto, se une a nuestras sesiones de testing con usuarios, a nuestros design jams, y a nuestras sesiones de planificación de conversaciones editoriales. Y ha hecho un trabajo increíble pasándole ese conocimiento al resto de nuestros ingenieros del equipo, así que realmente es como esta mentalidad de recibir ese feedback tan importante de nuestros periodistas, entender sus puntos de dolor (pain points) y después compartirlo y enseñarlo a todo el equipo.

text: In order to stay competitive in our modern news landscape, building this content management platform and the technology behind it has taught us how to enable rapid development and integration of new features and workflows. And we've been able to quickly test hypotheses while reducing risk, and again, time is of the essence when it comes to breaking news. And when you layer that with a very complex content management technology, there's a lot of moving parts. And we've been able to do that successfully, and it's pretty amazing. And because of that we've developed, I think, this unique skill of high agency under high pressure.
speaker: Upasna Gautam
context: Lenny asks what skills and approaches Upasna would take to future product teams from her experience at CNN. Upasna explains how building a content management platform in the fast-paced news environment has taught her team to enable rapid development while managing complex technology with many moving parts. She emphasizes that the combination of speed requirements for breaking news and technical complexity has helped them develop what she calls 'high agency under high pressure.'
text_ko: 현대 뉴스 환경에서 경쟁력을 유지하려면 이 콘텐츠 관리 플랫폼(content management platform)과 그 뒤에 있는 기술(content management technology)을 구축하면서 새로운 기능과 워크플로(workflow)를 빠르게 개발하고 통합하는 법을 배웠어요. 덕분에 가설을 빠르게 검증하면서 리스크를 줄일 수 있었고, 특히 속보(breaking news)에서는 시간이 정말 중요해요. 매우 복잡한 콘텐츠 관리 기술(content management technology)이 겹치면 움직이는 부분이 많아지는데, 저희는 그걸 성공적으로 해내고 있고 솔직히 꽤 대단하다고 생각해요. 그래서 저는 고압 상황에서 높은 실행력(high agency)을 발휘하는 독특한 능력을 갖추게 된 것 같아요.
text_zh: 要想在现在这个新闻环境里保持竞争力，我们搭建这套内容管理平台(content management platform)和背后的技术，让我们学会了怎么快速开发和整合新功能、新流程(workflow)。我们能够快速验证想法的同时还降低风险，再说一遍，做突发新闻就是跟时间赛跑。再加上内容管理技术本身就很复杂，里面有很多环节要配合。我们把这些都搞定了，真的挺厉害的。正因为这样，我觉得我们练就了一个独特的本事——在高压下还能保持高执行力。
text_es: Para mantenernos competitivos en el panorama mediático actual, desarrollar esta plataforma de gestión de contenidos y toda la tecnología que hay detrás nos ha enseñado cómo facilitar el desarrollo rápido y la integración de nuevas funciones y flujos de trabajo. Y hemos podido probar hipótesis rápidamente mientras reducimos el riesgo, y como ya dije, el tiempo es crucial cuando se trata de noticias de última hora. Y cuando le sumas una tecnología de gestión de contenidos muy compleja, hay muchas piezas en movimiento. Y lo hemos logrado con éxito, y es bastante impresionante. Y gracias a eso hemos desarrollado, creo yo, esta habilidad única de tener mucha autonomía bajo mucha presión.

text: When I asked my boss why he took such a big chance on me he said, 'It's because of your communication skills and relationship-building skills, and that I've seen you in a room where engineers listen to you and what you have to say, and you listen to them.' And he was like, 'That in itself is really, really hard to teach.' And I was like, 'Okay, yeah, I can do that.' So when I think about what communication means I also attach that to mindfulness. Like mindful communication is so critical for successful product management, no matter what type of product environment you're in.
speaker: Upasna Gautam
context: Lenny asks about practical tactics for dealing with unexpected events beyond meditation. Upasna shares advice her boss gave her about why he hired her for her first official product management role after a decade in tech infrastructure. She explains how her communication and relationship-building skills, particularly her ability to have engineers listen to her while also listening to them, was seen as especially valuable and difficult to teach.
vocabulary_highlights: took such a big chance on me
text_ko: 내가 사장님한테 왜 나한테 이렇게 큰 기회를 줬는지 물어봤을 때, 사장님이 이렇게 말씀하셨어요. '너의 커뮤니케이션 스킬과 관계 형성 능력 때문이야. 그리고 내가 너를 보았을 때, 엔지니어들이 너의 말을 듣고, 너도 그들의 이야기를 잘 들어주더라고.' 그게 정말 가르치기 힘든 부분이라고 하셨고, 나는 '아, 그럴 수 있겠구나'라고 생각했어요. 그래서 커뮤니케이션이 뭔지 생각할 때, 나는 그것을 마음 챙김(mindfulness)과 연결 지어요. 마음 챙김 커뮤니케이션은 어떤 제품 환경에서든 성공적인 제품 관리에 정말 중요하다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我问我老板为什么敢冒这么大风险用我，他说："就是因为你的沟通能力和建立关系的能力，我看到过你在会议室里，工程师们都愿意听你说话，而你也会认真听他们的意见。"他接着说："这种能力真的很难教会别人。"我当时就想："好吧，这个我确实能做到。"所以现在我一想到沟通，就会联想到用心这个概念。用心的沟通对于成功的产品管理(product management)来说太关键了，不管你在什么样的产品环境里都是这样。
text_es: Cuando le pregunté a mi jefe por qué se arriesgó tanto conmigo, me dijo: "Es por tus habilidades de comunicación y para construir relaciones, y porque te he visto en reuniones donde los ingenieros te escuchan y prestan atención a lo que dices, y tú también los escuchas a ellos." Y me dijo: "Eso en sí mismo es súper difícil de enseñar." Y yo le dije: "Ah, sí, eso sí lo puedo hacer." Entonces cuando pienso en lo que significa la comunicación, también lo relaciono con el mindfulness. La comunicación consciente (mindful communication) es súper crítica para la gestión exitosa de productos, sin importar en qué tipo de ambiente de producto estés trabajando.
